Award.AwardTitle: Finite-time Containment Control for Lagrangian Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:

The objective of this research is to address the problem of distributed finite-time containment control for Lagrangian networks. Despite the fact that each topic of containment control, finite-time control of networked systems, and control of Lagrangian networks is crucial for networked multi-agent systems, there are few existing results on each topic not to mention a combination of the three due to numerous inherent challenges. This research addresses a combination of the three topics in a unified framework.

Intellectual Merit:

Distributed algorithms will be designed to guarantee finite-time containment control for Lagrangian networks with stationary leaders, dynamic leaders, and swarming behavior and will be experimentally validated on heterogeneous robotic networks. The novelty of the research lies in the paradigm changes i) from leaderless or single leader behaviors dominantly studied in multi-agent systems to more realistic but complicated multi-leader multi-follower behaviors involving multi-layer collaboration between multiple heterogeneous teams of agents, ii) from distributed algorithms that can only guarantee asymptotic or at most exponential convergence in infinite time dominantly explored in multi-agent systems to distributed algorithms that are guaranteed to converge in finite time to meet the needs of many time-critical missions, and iii) from simplified/idealized linear point models dominantly adopted in multi-agent systems to more realistic and prevalent nonlinear Lagrangian models that represent a large class of mechanical systems including autonomous vehicles and robotic manipulators.

Broader Impacts:

The research has impact on numerous civilian, homeland security, and military applications and on other fields related to networked systems including biology, sociology, and physics. A capstone course on autonomous systems will be developed with emphasis on hands-on labs and campus-wide robotics competitions. Outreach activities to high school students will be pursued through involvement in a state-wide engineering program in Utah, Engineering State. Broad dissemination of the research results will be accomplished through publications, tutorial workshops, a summer school, and a dedicated website.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many complicated and important problems often call for collaboration of multiple heterogeneous teams of agents. Here different teams might have different sensing, communication, or actuation capabilities and/or have different levels of knowledge on overall mission objectives. Current research activities in networked control systems often focus on a leaderless or a single leader framework such as consensus or synchronization. Despite its importance, the current framework cannot address these problems. Instead, it is more appropriate to address these problems in a containment control framework where a first team of agents, called followers, is driven by a second team of agents, called leaders, to be in the possibly changing convex hull spanned by the second team and persistently remain in the convex hull afterwards. In this NSF funded research, the problem of distributed finite-time containment control for Lagrangian networks is addressed in a unified framework. Despite the fact that each topic of containment control, finite-time control of networked systems, and control of Lagrange networks is crucial for networked multi-agent systems, there are few existing results on each topic not to mention a combination of the three due to numerous inherent challenges. This research designs and analyzes novel distributed algorithms that guarantee containment control for Lagrange networks with stationary leaders, dynamic leaders, and swarming behavior. The key outcomes include distributed finite-time containment control and containment control with swarm tracking behavior for Lagrange networks,  fully distributed adaptive sliding-mode controller design, distributed containment control for multiple unknown second-order nonlinear systems with application to Lagrange networks, distributed adaptive containment control for Lagrange networks in directed networks without using neighbors’ velocity information, distributed containment control with multiple stationary or dynamic leaders in fixed and switching directed networks, surrounding control for cooperative agent networks, and decentralized finite-time sliding mode estimators. The distributed containment control algorithms derived in the project are also experimentally validated on a multi-vehicle testbed.

 

In terms of intellectual merit, the novelty of the research lies in the paradigm changes i) from leaderless or single leader behaviors dominantly studied in multi-agent systems to more realistic but complicated multi-leader multi-follower behaviors involving multi-layer collaboration between multiple heterogeneous teams of agents, ii) from distributed algorithms that can only guarantee asymptotic or at most exponential convergence in infinite time dominantly explored in multi-agent systems to distributed algorithms that are guaranteed to converge in finite time to meet the needs of many time-critical missions, and iii) from simplified/idealized linear point models dominantly adopted in multi-agent systems to more realistic and prevalent nonlinear Lagrange models that represent a large class of mechanical systems including autonomous vehicles and robotic manipulators.


In terms of broader impacts, the research has impact on numerous civilian, homeland security, and military applications and on other fields related to networked systems. The project has educational activities including robotics competition and outreach for high school students.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2015
Modified by: Wei Ren

Here different teams might have different sensing, communication, or actuation capabilities and/or have different levels of knowledge on overall mission objectives. Current research activities in networked control systems often focus on a leaderless or a single leader framework such as consensus or synchronization. Despite its importance, the current framework cannot address these problems. Instead, it is more appropriate to address these problems in a containment control framework where a first team of agents, called followers, is driven by a second team of agents, called leaders, to be in the possibly changing convex hull spanned by the second team and persistently remain in the convex hull afterwards. In this NSF funded research, the problem of distributed finite-time containment control for Lagrangian networks is addressed in a unified framework. Despite the fact that each topic of containment control, finite-time control of networked systems, and control of Lagrange networks is crucial for networked multi-agent systems, there are few existing results on each topic not to mention a combination of the three due to numerous inherent challenges. This research designs and analyzes novel distributed algorithms that guarantee containment control for Lagrange networks with stationary leaders, dynamic leaders, and swarming behavior. The key outcomes include distributed finite-time containment control and containment control with swarm tracking behavior for Lagrange networks, fully distributed adaptive sliding-mode controller design, distributed containment control for multiple unknown second-order nonlinear systems with application to Lagrange networks, distributed adaptive containment control for Lagrange networks in directed networks without using neighborsÆ velocity information, distributed containment control with multiple stationary or dynamic leaders in fixed and switching directed networks, surrounding control for cooperative agent networks, and decentralized finite-time sliding mode estimators. The distributed containment control algorithms derived in the project are also experimentally validated on a multi-vehicle testbed. In terms of intellectual merit, the novelty of the research lies in the paradigm changes i) from leaderless or single leader behaviors dominantly studied in multi-agent systems to more realistic but complicated multi-leader multi-follower behaviors involving multi-layer collaboration between multiple heterogeneous teams of agents, ii) from distributed algorithms that can only guarantee asymptotic or at most exponential convergence in infinite time dominantly explored in multi-agent systems to distributed algorithms that are guaranteed to converge in finite time to meet the needs of many time-critical missions, and iii) from simplified/idealized linear point models dominantly adopted in multi-agent systems to more realistic and prevalent nonlinear Lagrange models that represent a large class of mechanical systems including autonomous vehicles and robotic manipulators.
